column2: "steps": ["Mix together. Bring to a boil and boil for 1 minute. Add vanilla. Cool partially
column3: then beat with a mixer for 3 minutes or until spreadable consistency."
column4: "CDKitchen Note: Please read the reviews on this recipe. We have personally tested this recipe and it WORKS if you follow the directions."
column5: "This recipe has received such varying reviews we thought we better bring it to the CDTestKitchen. You'll notice we're giving it 5 stars - that's because it turned out perfect for us. We boiled the mixture about a minute (maybe 20-30 seconds more) then let it cool just a little (in case it splatted it wouldn't burn then!) and beat it with an electric mixer for about 3 1/2 minutes. We used all the measurements/ingredients exactly as called for in the recipe. One thing that may be confusing people is that this is not a fluffy kind of frosting that you use to decorate a cake. This is more of a frosting that would go on brownies
column6: or a cake that is in a pan. The mixture will harden some however
column7: but it definitely shouldn't be soupy like some reviewers mentioned. Be careful not to heat it over too high a heat
column8: or the sugar will start to turn to candy (which will make the mixture crunchy). We think the biggest success factor is the mixing time/technique. Don't try to mix this by hand
column9: you won't get it to the right consistency. Also
column10: don't let it cool too much before spreading it since it will firm up more while it cools (to the point it won't be easily spreadable)."]}

column2: "steps": ["For the cake:\u00a0Preheat the oven to 300 degrees F."

column4: "Put the egg whites in the bowl of an electric mixer. Be SURE that the bowl is clean and dry

column2: "steps": ["Using a ladle
column3: fill 2 cork molds with chocolate. When they are full
column4: empty the excess back into the bowl of chocolate. The inside of the molds should be evenly coated with chocolate. Wipe the lip of the molds clean and place them upside down on a wire rack over a baking sheet to drain. Once the chocolate starts to harden
column5: about 5 minutes
column6: use a wide pastry scraper to clean the edges of each cavity clean. This is important because when the chocolate sets
column7: it shrinks or retracts from the sides of the mold. A clean edge will keep it from sticking and cracking as it shrinks. You can place the mold in the refrigerator for several minutes to help the chocolate to harden."
column8: "Place the champagne and cream into a small saucepan and heat the mixture to a boil. Pour the hot champagne mixture over the chopped chocolate and corn syrup and blend until smooth with an immersion hand blender. Add the marc du champagne and the butter and blend until smooth with an immersion hand blender. Allow the mixture to cool until it has a thick consistency (thick enough to pipe). Place the mixture in a piping bag and pipe it into the chocolate filled molds. Let set overnight. Close the bottom of one mold by apply chocolate with an offset spatula. Scrape clean then press the two molds together evenly. Allow to set. When the chocolate has set
column9: remove the whole \"corks\" from the molds."
column10: "How to Temper Chocolate(From Dessert Circus
column11: Extraordinary Desserts You Can Make At Home by Jacques Torres):"
column12: "Chocolate is tempered so that after it has been melted
column13: it retains its gloss and hardens again without becoming chalky and white (that happens when the molecules of fat separate and form on top of the chocolate). There are a variety of ways to temper."
column14: "One of the easiest ways to temper chocolate is to chop it into small pieces and then place it in the microwave for 30 seconds at a time on high power until most of the chocolate is melted. Be very careful not to overheat it. (The temperature of dark chocolate should be between 88 and 90 degrees F
column15: slightly warmer than your bottom lip. It will retain its shape even when mostly melted. White and milk chocolates melt at a temperature approximately 2 degrees F less because of the amount of lactose they contain.) Any remaining lumps will melt in the chocolate's residual heat. Use an immersion blender or whisk to break up the lumps. Usually
column16: chocolate begins to set
column17: or crystallize
column18: along the side of the bowl. As it sets
column19: mix those crystals into the melted chocolate to temper it. A glass bowl retains heat well and keeps the chocolate tempered longer."
column20: "Another way to temper chocolate is called seeding. In this method
column21: add small pieces of unmelted chocolate to melted chocolate. The amount of unmelted chocolate to be added depends on the temperature of the melted chocolate
column22: but is usually 1/4 of the total amount. It is easiest to use an immersion blender for this
column23: or a whisk."
column24: "The classic way to temper chocolate is called tabliering. Two thirds of the melted chocolate is poured onto a marble or another cold work surface. The chocolate is spread out and worked with a spatula until its temperature is approximately 81 degrees F. At this stage
column25: it is thick and begins to set. This tempered chocolate is then added to the remaining non-tempered chocolate and mixed thoroughly until the mass has a completely uniform temperature. If the temperature is still too high
column26: part of the chocolate is worked further on the cold surface until the correct temperature is reached. This is a lot of work
column27: requires a lot of room
column28: and makes a big mess."
column29: "A simple method of checking tempering
column30: is to apply a small quantity of chocolate to a piece of paper or to the point of a knife. If the chocolate has been correctly tempered
column31: it will harden evenly and show a good gloss within a few minutes."]}

column9: "Custom Mustard"
column10: "Your imagination's the limit when it comes to making flavored mustard. All you need are mustard seeds or dry mustard powder
column11: and then the seasonings are up to you."
column12: "Mustard seeds or mustard powder?"
column13: "Either works."
column14: "Mustard seeds: Use when you want a whole-grain
column15: crunchy texture. The three types are yellow
column16: aka white (Sinapis alba)
column17: the mildest and used mainly in American-style mustards and for pickling; brown (Brassica juncea)
column18: zestier and used in European-style mustards (like Dijon)
column19: for pickling
column20: and in Indian cooking; and black (B. nigra)
column21: also used in Indian food; they're interchangeable with the brown. Seeds need to soften in liquid for 1 to 2 days before you make mustard with them."
column22: "Mustard powder: For silky smooth mustard. It's nothing more than ground mustard seed
column23: and the most common brand is Colman's
column24: a blend of white and brown seeds. Mix the powder with liquid (like water or beer) and let it sit overnight to fully hydrate and develop flavor. Don't let it sit longer
column25: though
column26: or it will taste harsh."]}

column2: "steps": ["Soak the mustard seeds: Combine all ingredients in a quart jar or other sealable nonreactive container. Seal and refrigerate overnight

column5: "Prepare the jars and lids: Wash all jars and lids thoroughly with soap and water and rinse well. Fill your canner with enough water to cover the jars by at least 1 inch and bring to a simmer. Using a pair of canning tongs
column6: lower the jars in gently
column7: tilting them to fill with the hot water. In a small saucepan

column16: "Fill and close the jars: Using canning tongs

column19: leaving 1/2-inch headspace at the top. Run a clean chopstick around the inside of the jar to dislodge any trapped air. Wipe the rims of the jars with a damp paper towel. Place the lids on
column20: and screw on the rings until just finger-tight."
column21: "Seal the jars: Using canning tongs
column22: gently transfer the jars to the canner
column23: taking care to keep them vertical. When all the jars are in the canner
column24: there should be at least 1 inch of water covering them; if you need more
column25: add water from the kettle until the jars are sufficiently covered. Bring the water to a full rolling boil
column26: and process for 10 minutes."
column27: "Remove and cool: Using canning tongs
column28: gently remove the jars from the canner and transfer them to a kitchen towel or cooling rack
column29: again keeping them vertical. Do not set hot jars directly on to cool counter surfaces. Leave to cool
column30: undisturbed
column31: for at least 12 hours. If any of the jars do not seal when cool
column33: or refrigerate and use immediately."
column34: "Label and store: Add a label to the lid or side of your jar
column35: noting the date it was canned. Remove the rings and store jars in a cool

column2: "steps": ["I like to begin the platter with a base of ripe
column3: colorful
column4: sliced melons and pineapple--for example
column5: cantaloupe
column6: honeydew
column7: Galia
column8: or Cavaillon melons
column9: plus the new \"golden\" pineapples. Peel the outside of a whole melon
column10: cut it in half through the stem end
column11: and scoop out the seeds. Place the melon halves cut side down on a board
column12: and slice them straight across into 1/2-inch-thick slices. Fan each half-melon out slightly and arrange it on the platter. Next
column13: cut off the top and bottom of the pineapple
column14: peel the outside
column15: and use a sharp knife to remove the \"eyes.\" Cut the pineapple in half lengthwise and remove the core by cutting a \"V\" down the center of each half. Again
column16: place the pineapple halves
column17: cut side down
column18: on a board and slice them straight across into 1/2-inch-thick slices. Fan the slices out and arrange them next to the melon on the platter."
column19: "Once the base is set
column20: you can add any kind of fruit that's available. I like to have one thing that is taller than the rest
column21: such as a large bunch of grapes or a decoratively cut papaya
column22: to give the platter height. Then I add raspberries
column23: strawberries
column24: blueberries
column25: and fresh figs in casual but organized groups. The platter can look like a bowl of M&M's if there are too many colors scattered with no order. Visually
column26: your eye needs to have a focal point and to be able to see each type of fruit. After all the fruit is arranged
column27: I add flat green leaves around the outside of the fruit
column28: to set off the colors. Use lemon and galax leaves from your florist
column29: or fig leaves and grape leaves from your garden. Make sure they are pesticide-free and well washed."
column30: "Any kind of fruit will work well on this platter. For special occasions
column31: add persimmons
column33: passion fruit
column34: Queen Anne cherries
column35: fresh apricots
column36: and mangos. Choose whatever is colorful and seasonal."]}

Immediately check the oil temperature and adjust the flame so that the temperature does not drop below 300 degrees F; maintain the temperature at 325 to 350 degrees F. As it cooks

Repeat this with the other half of dough. Gather the scraps of both halves and re-roll to create more rectangles\u00a0(you will get 6 to 8 more)."

column14: "Secrets for Fantastic Ribs:"
column15: "USE PORK SPARERIBS AND BEEF SHORT RIBS. More generously marbled than pork baby back ribs
column16: country-style spareribs
column17: or regular beef ribs
column18: they're noticeably more juicy and flavorful."
column19: "TRIM SPARERIBS ST. LOUIS-STYLE. Meaning
column20: trim them into a tidy
column21: rectangular shape that cooks evenly. Ask a butcher to trim them
column22: or do it yourself: On the bony side
column23: trim the flap of meat from the center
column24: flush with the bones. Then cut the rack lengthwise between the 4- to 5-in.-wide rib section and the chewy skirt (above). Save scraps for soup."
column25: "REMOVE THE MEMBRANE. Pork spareribs have a membrane on the underside that can shrink up and make the meat cook unevenly. It's easy to remove: Slide the tip of a meat thermometer under the membrane at one end to loosen an edge. Pull off membrane with a paper towel (it may come off in pieces) while holding the rack down with your other hand."
column26: "Setting Up Your Grill:"
column27: "MASTER THE ART OF INDIRECT HEAT. This allows the ribs to cook long and slow
column28: so they become extremely tender and rendered of much of their fat. Then brown them over the direct-heat part of the fire."
column29: "If using gas
column30: put a drip pan in place under one part of the cooking grate (the indirect-heat area)
column31: then light only the burner or burners on the rest of the grill (the direct-heat area)."
column33: ignite 50 briquets in a chimney
column34: then bank coals on opposite sides of firegrate
column35: leaving a cleared area in the middle. Set a drip pan in the cleared area. Let coals burn down to the temperature specified in the recipe. To maintain the temp during cooking
column36: add 5 briquets to each mound of coals about every 30 minutes
column37: starting when ribs go on grill; if fire gets too hot
column38: partially close vents under grill and on lid."

column13: "A Three-Step Guide to Puttin' Up"
column14: "Yes
column15: it really is that easy. To get started
column16: you'll need a basic canner
column17: a jar lifter
column18: and a canning rack. Look for a 9- or 12-piece canning kit
column19: which will include all of these pieces and more."
column20: "Step 1: Sterilize."
column21: "Bring a canner half full of water to a boil; simmer. Place jars in a large stockpot with water to cover; bring to a boil
column22: and simmer 10 minutes. Place bands and lids in a large saucepan. (Always use new lids.) Using a ladle
column23: cover bands and lids with hot water from canner to soften gaskets. Let stand 10 minutes."
column24: "Step 2: Prepare Recipe."
column25: "Meanwhile
column26: prepare recipe. Remove hot jars from stockpot
column27: 1 at a time
column28: using jar lifter
column29: and fill as directed in recipe."
column30: "Step 3: Seal & Process."
column31: "Wipe rims of filled jars. Cover at once with metal lids
column32: and screw on bands (snug but not too tight). Place jars in canning rack
column33: and place in simmering water in canner. Add more boiling water as needed to cover jars by 1 to 2 inches. Bring water to a rolling boil; boil 15 minutes
column34: adjusting processing time for altitude.* Turn off heat
column35: and let stand 5 minutes. Remove jars from canner
column36: and let stand at room temperature 24 hours. Test seals of jars by pressing centers of lids. If lids do not pop
column37: jars are properly sealed. Store in a cool
column38: dark place at room temperature up to 1 year. Refrigerate after opening."
column39: "*Consult the USDA Complete Guide to Home Canning at nchfp.uga.edu/publications/publications_usda.html to adjust processing times for altitude."]}

column2: "steps": ["Add the peppercorns to the vodka and allow to sit in a cool dark place for 7 days. Stir or gently shake to combine every few days. After 7 days
column3: strain through a fine mesh strainer to remove the peppercorns. Place in a sterilized* glass container with a lid and store in a cool dark place."
column4: "Tips on Sterilizing Jars Properly-handled sterilized equipment will keep canned foods in good condition for years. Sterilizing jars is the first step of preserving foods."
column5: "Sterilizing Tips: Jars should be made from glass and free of any chips or cracks. Preserving or canning jars are topped with a glass
column6: plastic
column7: or metal lid
column8: which has a rubber seal. Two piece lids are best for canning
column9: as they vacuum seal when processed. To sterilize jars
column10: before filling with jams
column11: pickles
column12: or preserves
column13: wash jars and lids with hot
column14: soapy water. Rinse well and arrange jars and lids open sides up
column15: without touching
column16: on a tray. Boil the jars and lids in a large saucepan
column17: covered with water
column18: for 15 minutes. Use tongs when handling the hot sterilized jars
column19: to move them from boiling water. Be sure the tongs are sterilized too
column20: by dipping the ends in boiling water for a few minutes. As a rule
column21: hot preserves go into hot jars and cold preserves go into cold jars. All items used in the process of making jams
column22: jellies
column23: and preserves must be clean. This includes any towels used
column24: and especially your hands. After the jars are sterilized
column25: you can preserve the food. It is important to follow any canning and processing instructions included in the recipe and refer to USDA guidelines about the sterilization of canned products."]}

The thermometer should read about 130 degrees F for medium rare. column2: "steps": ["This is the most important part: Wash the rice! Place the rice in a large bowl and fill with fresh
column3: room temperature water. Swirl your hand through the water and the rice; the water will go cloudy. That's all the starch that we're trying to remove in order to have individual grains of rice
column4: not the sticky kind that's popular in Chinese and Japanese cuisine. (According to traditional Indian wisdom
column5: this also makes the rice easier to digest because so much of the starch has been removed). Once you've swirled your hand around for a minute or so
column6: pour off the water
column7: taking care not to lose any rice. Repeat this washing process until the water runs clear. Usually
column8: this takes 3 or 4 changes of water."
column9: "Fill up the bowl 1 more time and let the rice soak for 30 minutes."
column10: "At the end of 30 minutes
column11: drain the rice. Fill a medium saucepan with 1 3/4 cups water
column12: add a pinch of salt
column13: and bring to a boil."
column14: "Add the rice
column15: stir
column16: and wait until the water comes back to a full boil. When it does
column17: turn the heat down as low as it can go
column18: and then cover. Cook for 15 minutes."
column19: "At the end of 15 minutes
column20: cut the heat. Let the rice sit for 5 minutes. Fluff with a fork; you should see that every grain of rice has grown a little longer and is separate from its brothers and sisters. Well done!"]}

column2: "steps": ["For the pasta dough: Put the flour on a clean dry work surface. Make a hole (this is also called a well) in the center of the flour pile that is about 8 inches wide (bigger is definitely better here). Crack the eggs and yolk into the hole
column3: and add the olive oil
column4: salt and water."
column5: "Using a fork
column6: beat the eggs together with the olive oil
column7: water and salt
column8: and then begin to incorporate the flour into the egg mixture. (Be careful not to break the sides of the well
column9: or the egg mixture will run all over your work surface and you'll have a big mess! Also
column10: don't worry about lumps.) When enough flour has been incorporated into the egg mixture that it won't run all over the place
column11: begin to use your hands to get everything well combined. If the mixture is tight and dry
column12: wet your hands and begin kneading with wet hands. When the mixture has really come together into a homogeneous mixture
column13: THEN you can start kneading."
column14: "When kneading
column15: it is VERY important to put your body weight into it--get on top of the dough to really stretch
column16: not tear
column17: it. Using the heels of your palms
column18: roll the dough to create a smooooooth
column19: supple dough. When done
column20: the dough should look VERY smooth and feel almost velvety. Kneading will usually take from 8 to 10 minutes for an experienced kneader or 10 to 15 minutes for an inexperienced kneader. This is where the perfect
column21: toothsome texture of your pasta is formed. Get in there and have fun!"
column22: "When the pasta has been kneaded to the perfect consistency
column23: wrap it in plastic and let rest for at least 1 hour."

column35: "Add the chicken stock

column38: being careful not to overcook the shrimp and squid or else they'll be rubbery."

column2: "steps": ["Preheat oven to 375 degrees."

Work quickly so the egg white does not deflate (or sift through a strainer onto a sheet of waxed paper). Fold into egg whites 1/3 at a time. Fold in the vanilla and tangerine zest. Gently spoon the mixture into an ungreased tube pan. Smooth the top and bake 30 to 35 minutes

column11: as you whisk

column13: so proceed carefully

column30: "Veggie-friendly wines:"
column31: "SAUVIGNON BLANC: Rochioli Sauvignon Blanc 2007 (Russian River Valley; $26). Rich and complex; lively herbs; exotic mix of Asian pear
column33: lemongrass. Signaterra (by Benziger Family) Shone Farm Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc 2007 (Russian River Valley; $26). Lovely new-mown grass and herb aromas followed by a splash of grapefruit."
column34: "SPARKLING WINE: Gruet Blanc de Blancs 2004 (New Mexico; $25). A delightful sparkler with fresh grapefruit
column35: melons
column36: and pears over faint tropical notes. Schramsberg Blanc de Blancs 2005 (North Coast; $36). Crisp apple and creamy lemon blend with stone fruit and a yummy toasted character."
column37: "DRY RIESLING: Claiborne & Churchill Dry Riesling 2006 (Central Coast; $18). Fuzzy apricots and peaches balanced by minerals and a touch of classic Riesling diesel-fuel quality (a good thing). Trefethen Family Dry Riesling 2007 (Oak Knoll District
column39: with lemon zest and beautiful stone fruit."
column40: "DRY GEW\u00dcRZTRAMINER: Londer Dry Gew\u00fcrztraminer 2007 (Anderson Valley; $26). Perfumed with honeysuckle and juicy with stone fruit and citrus. Stony Hill Gew\u00fcrztraminer 2006 (Napa Valley; $21). True to its name\u2014full of wet stones
column41: plus flowers and spice and satisfyingly bitter grapefruit."
